text: Theresa May is today at the g20 in China
hobnobbing with other world leaders on
Friday however she invited us to her
Maidenhead constituency to give her
first impressions of the task facing the
government as it unwinds its
relationships with the EU and I started
by asking her by that striking speech
she gave outside Downing Street when she
became the first Prime Minister first as
she promised to take action against what
she calls the burning in justices around
Britain frankly I wanted to know did she
mean it well I want to see a country
that works for everyone
Andrew and that's what's going to be the
driving force of my government and
that's looking at a society that works
for everyone an economy that works for
everyone so are we looking across the
board at issues like schools and
hospitals and opportunities to ensure
that people can actually get on and take
those opportunities regardless of their
background but is about their talents
and their willingness to work in
concrete terms there's a lot of people
on your side of politics who would say
that in terms of Education grammar
schools are the way forward that's what
got people you went to a Grammar School
it then became a comprehensive lots of
people like you got to the top by going
to grammar schools are you prepared to
allow more grammar schools to open and
existing grammar schools to expand what
I want to doing looking at schools is to
build on the success of the six years
under David Cameron's Premiership when
we've seen now see more children in good
and outstanding schools but there is
still more to be done there is still
parents who feel that their children
aren't getting the opportunities they
want them to have because of what
happens at their local school so I want
to make sure that children have those
opportunities that all schools are
offering a good education for children
start quite advance my question about
grammar schools though well just in
greening was on your your programme and
said you'd be looking at these issues
which he is doing so we will look at the
work that Justine is doing but the
abiding theme that I want to ensure is
there is that of giving opportunity to
young people of ensuring that whatever
school anybody is going to wherever they
are in whatever part of the country
they're actually able to enjoy able to
ensure they get that good quality of
education that gives them the
opportunities to get on in life would
you like to see at the end of the first
Teresa may administer
more grammar schools are open than there
are now what I'd like to see andrew is
ensuring an education system regardless
of where people are regardless of the
school they're going to that is ensuring
that they're getting the quality of
education that enables them to take on
those opportunities because when I talk
about a country that works for everyone
it's about ensuring that whatever
people's talents are it's about how far
their talents can take them but it's
also about obviously government ensuring
that those jobs and opportunities are
there for everybody and I think that
there are sadly some people in the
country who do feel that actually
benefits of what's happened over the
last few years have gone to other people
and not to them it's ensuring that it is
that government and country that works
for everyone so if you're going to
operate on the basis that people at the
bottom of the heap as it were why did
you water down the obesity strategy for
instance whether those are very very
carefully worked out complicated
thought-through strategy to help the
problem of obesity which particularly
affects poorer people and it was
dismantled at the last moment well what
we've come forward with is I think an
obesity strategy that is going to work
an obesity strategy that will have an
impact on people through the work that
we'll be doing in terms of reductions of
sugar and so forth which is it that
there's a there isn't an issue here I
think which is first of all you say we
want to obviously help those who are at
the bottom of the society but I also
want to help as I said on the de steps
of Downing Street those people who are
perhaps in work but for whom life is
still a struggle and I think it's often
those people who feel that they've been
particularly left behind but if it's not
to be more than warm words you have to
take on some of the big interests and it
did seem that you cited in the end with
the big food companies and the
advertisers rather than the medical
people and the lobbyists on the obesity
issue I've been very clear that I'm not
afraid to take on the big interests when
I spoke in Birmingham at the start of
what was going to be the the national
leadership campaign of course things
turned out a little differently I spoke
about the importance of actually dealing
with irresponsible behavior in companies
so as you would have seen in my time as
Home Secretary I'm not afraid to take on
big interests
I think that is the right thing to do
now you've already mentioned the B word
so let's talk about brexit bricks it
means brexit you've said but what does
bricks it mean it well it's about coming
out of the European Union at its
simplest it's about listening to the
British people were the only party now
that is actually saying that we're
prepared to accept the vote that people
gave and we've listened to people and we
will now make a success of that
obviously there's going to be a period
of negotiations but what I'm very clear
about particularly and this is a message
I'll be taking the g20 in China is that
this is not about the United Kingdom
suddenly wanting to be inward-looking
actually we will be continue to be a
bold outward looking country we want to
forge new deals we want to be an
independent Britain forging our own way
in the world at Chequers you made it
clear that as far as you're concerned
part of what BRICS it means is strict
controls on immigration will your
successor as Home Secretary if she's in
the job a say in four or five years time
be able if she chooses to say no
immigration at all or only a dribble
from the EU but what the vote what
leaving the European Union does enable
us to do is yes to say what I think the
British people were very clear about
which is that they don't want free
movement to continue in the way that it
has done in the past they do want to see
controls of movement of people coming in
from the European Union but people also
want to see the job opportunities to see
the economic opportunities and so
getting a good deal in trade and service
in trade in goods and services is also
obviously important for us and so this
is the problem as the Chancellor Philip
Hammond has said it's very very
important to get access to European
markets particularly for the banking
sector the finance sector but many
others as well as you may have to do
trades in terms of the amount of people
you allow in from the EU it might not be
quite an end to free movement to people
if you want full access to those markets
are you prepared to do those trades
well what I'm very clear about is that
we need to take some time to prepare the
position that we want to take is the
United Kingdom that's why I've said that
we won't trigger this article 50 that
starts the formal negotiation process
with the EU before the end of before the
end of this year
so we're taking that time David Davis is
the Secretary of State
he'll be making a statement to
Parliament this week about the work that
the government has been doing over the
summer and obviously how we're going to
take that forward in shaping the sort of
relationship we want with the EU it's a
matter of huge moment to a lot of people
exactly when that article 50 moment is
triggered because that's the start of
the process the clock starts ticking and
so forth
if we were talking this time next year
would article 50 have been triggered by
then well I don't think it should be
triggered before the end of the year
because I think we need to have a period
of preparation and I think it's actually
good for the rest of the European Union
that they're also to have able to have
that period of preparation so that when
we start the process of negotiations the
process I think will be smoother and we
can ensure that there is as little
disruption as possible
but I'm very clear also that the British
people don't want the issue of article
50 being triggered just being kicked
into the long grass in your view should
we have access to the single European
market well what I want to see is the
best possible deal for the United
Kingdom in trade in goods and services I
don't want to adopt direction but I
don't want I don't adopt a particular
model and people use phrases about
access to the market about customs
unions and so forth I prefer to look at
it and say let's work out what the best
deal for us would be in trade in goods
and services and then let's be ambitious
and go out there and fight for it
as you head off the g20 ever wants to
hear more about brexit and how it's
going and so forth
but you leave with economic figures they
could hardly be better employments right
up consumer confidence is very very
strong indeed and we've had some
excellent manufacturing index figures so
that suggests that all those people who
said that brexit would put a bomb under
the British economy or be a DIY
recession I think the former Chancellor
of the Exchequer said all of that was
scare mongering well we have had some
good figures and better figures than
some had predicted would would be the
case but what is important for us now is
that we maintain that policy of ensuring
economic stability and a strong economy
for the future part of that is going to
be as we come out of the European Union
ensuring we've got trade deals around
the world I want the United Kingdom to
be a global leader in four
trade and one of these things I'll be
doing at the g20 is emphasizing the role
that we will be playing in the world but
also in a number of the discussions I'll
be having with President Obama for
example Prime Minister Modi promised to
turn back about Hume well we'll be
talking about I want to talk about how
we can start to scope out what a trade
deal and the negotiations on a trade
deal would be like so that when the Tong
time comes when we're able to sign those
deal we're ready to do so I suppose what
I'm getting to is that all those
warnings as I say about a bomb under the
British economy appear to be completely
wrong at the moment or do you think it's
simply too early to tell and there are
dangers ahead well I'm not going to
pretend that it's all going to be plain
sailing I think we must be prepared for
the fact that there may be some
difficult times ahead but what I am is
optimistic and indeed this was what the
message that came from the Cabinet when
we were sitting around the table at
checkers this week and talking about
these things it's the same message I've
had from businesses is an optimism about
the future about the opportunities that
are now open to the United Kingdom as I
say an independent Britain forging our
own way in the world now you use the
word British there but you also said
soon after you became Prime Minister
that you wanted this to be an all United
Kingdom thing and that you wanted the
Scots to be completely happy and
satisfied with the way things are going
the way the negotiations were going to
go before you triggered article 50 is
that still the case what I've said to
Nicola Sturgeon and the discussions I've
had with the Scottish Government is that
I want them to be fully involved
involved fully engaged in the
discussions that we're having about the
position the United Kingdom's going to
take and and the other devolved
administration's as well what you know
the people of the United Kingdom took a
decision to leave the European Union
what I want to do is make success of it
but I say to the people in Scotland is I
want to ensure that that's a success for
people in Scotland so I guess again what
I'm trying to get to is that Scotland
has very different views about some of
these issues for instance there is much
less worry about immigration among Scots
and certainly with the Scottish
Government will they have a proper input
into that process will Nicola Sturgeon
be influential in the brexit
negotiations
I want the Scottish Government and the
other devolved administration's to
being gauged with us as we determine the
position the United Kingdom is going to
take but the British people took a few
the United Kingdom took a view that we
should be leaving the European Union and
we could try and turn our back on that
we could try and say let's have a second
vote we could transcend riddims no
second referendum we could try and say
look this is you know we wish that
hadn't happened so we're going to try
and somehow wish it away what I'm saying
what the Conservative Party is saying
it's the only party that is saying this
is we respect the wishes of the British
people the British people want us to
leave the European Union and that's what
we will do in Scotland there is still a
feeling that we've we in Scotland voted
to stay we didn't vote the same way as
England and that we would like to stay
inside the EU that in itself is
triggering pressure for a second
Scottish independence referendum debate
it all summer if that came about would
you prevent that second referendum
happening
I don't think it's a question of whether
there could be a reference second
referendum it's whether there should be
a second referendum it was a vote of the
Scottish people in 2014 that they wanted
to say to your change
that they wanted to stay part of of the
United Kingdom there's been a vote of
the United Kingdom that it wants to come
out of the European Union
Scotland wasn't the only part of the UK
that voted over all voted remain rather
than to leave but the overall view of
the United Kingdom and the public was to
come out of the European Union as I say
we could try and you know some people
might say well let's try and Road back
on that let's try and find a way out of
that yes a vote was taken a decision was
taken the job now is to get on with it
but a lot of people watching and not
only in Scotland want to know whether if
there are proposals for a second
Scottish independence referendum quite
soon Theresa May as Prime Minister of
the UK would say no I'm not going to let
that happen I said I don't think it's a
question of whether there could be I
think it's a question of whether there
should be and I think if you look at
some of the results that have now coming
out of polling in Scotland they suggest
that the Scottish people don't want
there to be a second referendum let me
move on then to the position of people
born in the rest of the EU who are
living and working and contributing to
this economy at the moment there's
millions of them many of them are
watching and they are very very worried
about their own person
futures some of them are already going
home people in top jobs in universities
and elsewhere are quitting them and
returning to the continent because they
have not heard any reassuring words
particularly from you can you give them
some reassurance now well first of all
as long as we're still in the European
Union then the position of people who
were born in other European Union
countries and living in the UK doesn't
change their position remains their
status remains the same I want to be
able to guarantee their status for the
future I expect to be able to guarantee
their status for the future but the only
circumstances in which that wouldn't be
possible would be if the status of
British citizens living in other
European cut union countries was not
guaranteed and do you feel that could
happen I think it's important that we're
very clear that I expect the status of
British citizens in the other countries
in the European Union to be guaranteed
as I expect to be able to guarantee the
status of yyyy-you citizens living here
now we've talked about a possible
Scottish referendum and we've talked
about the timing of article 50 and so on
let me ask you about another election
which is the next general election
because if you look at the polling and a
lot of people in your party very excited
about this if you went to the country
now you get a majority of something like
114 or 130 that seems a wonderful
opportunity for you are you tempted in
any way to call a snap election I think
what's important particularly having had
the referendum vote is that we have a
period of stability there's a there's a
challenge ahead in May in ensuring that
we make a success of coming out of the
European Union I think it's important we
focus on that and the other reform
agenda that I have for the country as we
go forward and we'll be continuing the
manifesto on which the Conservative
government was elected in 2015 so I
don't think there's a need for an
election I think the next election would
be in 2020 let me make this very clear
because again is it very important under
current law the next election will be in
2020 no ifs no buts no snap elections no
changing the law under you is that
absolutely certain that we're not going
to see an election before int 20 I'm not
going to be calling a snap election I've
been very clear that I think we need
that period of jiying that stability to
be able to deal with the
that the country is facing and have that
election in 2020 you're off to the g20
when you will be meeting the Chinese now
if you pull the plug on Hinkley then you
would cause enormous offence in China it
will be a personal humiliation for the
Chinese president are you going to do
that yeah I'm looking at the Hinkley
decision but it's it's about how I
actually approach these things Andrew
which is I don't just come in and say
right this is the decision I take I look
at the evidence I take the advice I
listen to that that's what I'm still
doing I've said there will be a decision
in September so there will be decision
later this month one of your senior
advisors Nick Timothy said that he was
very worried about the security
implications of a communist country as
it were having its hands on the windpipe
of our nuclear industry they could put
in bugs into the system which meant they
could close down our electricity supply
do you share those worries about China
having a really important strategic
place at the center of our nuclear
industry what I'm doing is looking at
this decision looking across the board
at the various aspects of this decision
wanting across the board at the various
aspects of this decision and then we'll
come to come to a view as a result of
the work that that I'm doing as I say I
will come to a view in in September as
Home Secretary in the past of course and
as Prime Minister national security is a
key issue for us but in terms of that
individual decision I'll be looking at
all aspects of it and come to a decision
is up but it won't be quite something
wouldn't it have a communist country in
control of our nuclear industry because
they don't just want Hinkley they want
to build their own station at Brad wall
as well so this is a big big strategic
decision and yet if they are offended by
the way we approach this we are cutting
off our noses and spite in one of our
really really important partners in the
future post brexit so it's a really
tough decision for you isn't it I think
you're trying to get me to sort of give
an indicator I've got lettuce no one's
going to be Andrew which I'm not going
to do because as I say the way that I
the way that I work is to assemble the
evidence to look carefully at the
evidence and then come to a decision and
that's the process I'm going through to
